physDesc.p: This letter is two pages long. On the first page, the words “Poetry Monroe” are written in pencil at the top.

encodingDesc.p: This letter contains references to the following:

div.p: Of course, I take your letter exactly as you mean it, but I happen to be so husky just at this moment that I cannot feel that the disposition of my will are of any immediate importance.

The subject is not a new one to me. I have thought it over several times. Up to date, however, I have not been able to satisfy myself that it is a wise thing to endow the arts. It seems as if the recipients of these endowments were always the wrong people; and how one could arrange to get the right people in the line of prizes, I do not know. However, to paraphrase Gilbert and Sullivan:

quote.p: To the matter that you mention
I will give my best attention.

div.p: I have the cause of poetry as much at heart as you have, and I have thought of this for a long time; but whether the difficulties will be insurmountable in the end, I cannot now say.

I was very glad to hear what Mrs. Colum said
and I (indecipherable) myself. The attitude of New York is utterly inconceivable to me. I am bound to confess, I think perhaps Ezra’s articles, pitching into everything American, from the beginning of the magazine up to date, have had something to do with it. This is not a criticism upon your having him in; I am not Fletcher; he told me he had written to you, and then he showed me your letter in return, and I must say you are uncommonly generous to take criticisms as you do.

pb.p: By the way, Ezra’s new book “Cathay” is full of the most beautiful things. I have seldom read anything finer. What a pity the boy does not confine himself to working and leave strictures on other people’s work alone. I would rather like to review it, but I am a little afraid that, if I do, he will think I am trying to curry favour with him. What do you think?
